item.title: Does a github.io page work for me?
item.description: Here we go. I try to start my own website to write about things that are on my mind. Maybe this website will just hold links to all the work I did, e.g. publications. Since I got some experience with static site generators, I decided to give Hugo a try. Also, github.io pages need to be static. The GNU Radio website uses Hugo and I enjoy using it. Especially its local preview features are convincing.
item.content:
Here we go. I try to start my own website to write about things that are on my mind. Maybe this website will just hold links to all the work I did, e.g. publications.

Since I got some experience with static site generators, I decided to give Hugo a try. Also, github.io pages need to be static. The GNU Radio website uses Hugo and I enjoy using it. Especially its local preview features are convincing.

If you get used to GitHub Actions, you quite enjoy them. They’re simple to set up and automate things. I assume most people use them to run tests for every Pull Request and Push to a git repository. Hugo docs to deploy to github.io look quite convenient to use CD for once.

item.title: About me
item.description: About me My name is Johannes Demel (he/him). I’m with the Department of Communications Engineering (ANT) at the University of Bremen to pursue my PhD in Communications Engineering 📡. Besides, I’m a GNU Radio user and developer. Together with Michael Dickens, we maintain the Vector-Optimized Library of Kernels (VOLK). 🔭 I’m currently writing my PhD thesis 📕 which includes a GNU Radio demo where AGVs 🤖 use our communication system for ultra reliable low latency communication.
item.content:
About me

My name is Johannes Demel (he/him). I’m with the Department of Communications Engineering (ANT) at the University of Bremen to pursue my PhD in Communications Engineering 📡. Besides, I’m a GNU Radio user and developer. Together with Michael Dickens, we maintain the Vector-Optimized Library of Kernels (VOLK).

  • 🔭 I’m currently writing my PhD thesis 📕 which includes a GNU Radio demo where AGVs 🤖 use our communication system for ultra reliable low latency communication.

  • Most of my code is hosted under my GitHub profile.

  • You can find my LinkedIn profile here.

  • My profile at ANT

  • VOLK git repository

Professional experience 🖥️

  • 2019 till today

    • Co-maintainer of Vector-Optimized Library of Kernels (VOLK)

  • 2016 till today

    • Research Engineer with the Department of Communications Engineering (ANT) at the University of Bremen

  • 2013 to 2014

    • Internship at Ettus Research, Santa Clara, CA, USA

Education 🎓

  • 2016 till today

    • PhD student at University of Bremen in Communications Engineering

  • 2012 to 2016

    • Master degree in Electrical Engineering and Information Technology at Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, Germany, with a focus on Communications Engineering at the Communications Engineering Lab (CEL)

  • 2014

    • Erasmus semester at Wrocław University of Science and Technology, Poland

  • 2009 to 2012

    • Bachelor degree in Electrical Engineering and Information Technology at Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, Germany

  • 2009

    • Abitur at Georg Büchner Gymnasium, Winnenden, Germany

item.title: Presentations
item.description: Presentations This is a compilation of recorded presentations I’ve given. FOSDEM ‘21 VOLK project update At FOSDEM ‘21 I held the presentation: Vector Optimized Library of Kernels - A year in review in the Free Software Radio devroom. Burst error analysis of scheduling algorithms for 5G NR URLLC periodic deterministic communication The presentation is part of our publication Burst error analysis of scheduling algorithms for 5G NR URLLC periodic deterministic communication at the IEEE 91st Vehicular Technology Conference (VTC2020-Spring).
item.content:
Presentations

This is a compilation of recorded presentations I’ve given.

FOSDEM ‘21 VOLK project update

At FOSDEM ‘21 I held the presentation: Vector Optimized Library of Kernels - A year in review in the Free Software Radio devroom.

Burst error analysis of scheduling algorithms for 5G NR URLLC periodic deterministic communication

The presentation is part of our publication Burst error analysis of scheduling algorithms for 5G NR URLLC periodic deterministic communication at the IEEE 91st Vehicular Technology Conference (VTC2020-Spring).

gr-gfdm project presentation

At FOSDEM ‘18 I presented An optimized GFDM software implementation for low-latency in the Software Defined Radio devroom. The sources can be found in my git repository.

Polar codes in GNU Radio

This is a results presentation from my SOCIS Polar Codes work in GNU Radio at the GNU Radio Conference 2015 (GRCon15).

item.title: Publications
item.description: Publications This is a list of publications I compiled over the years with my ORCID: 0000-0002-5434-7232. Some of my publications are also available at the Department of Communications Engineering (ANT) homepage. My publications are listed on Google Scholar as well. Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy: Burst error analysis of scheduling algorithms for 5G NR URLLC periodic deterministic communication, 2020 IEEE 91st Vehicular Technology Conference (VTC2020-Spring), DOI: VTC2020-Spring48590.2020.9129493 Demel, Monsees, Bockelmann, Wübben, Dekorsy: Cloud-RAN Fronthaul Rate Reduction via IBM-based Quantization for Multicarrier Systems, 24th International ITG Workshop on Smart Antennas (WSA 2020), ISBN: 978-3-8007-5200-3
item.content:
Publications

This is a list of publications I compiled over the years with my ORCID: 0000-0002-5434-7232. Some of my publications are also available at the Department of Communications Engineering (ANT) homepage. My publications are listed on Google Scholar as well.

  • Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy: Burst error analysis of scheduling algorithms for 5G NR URLLC periodic deterministic communication, 2020 IEEE 91st Vehicular Technology Conference (VTC2020-Spring), DOI: VTC2020-Spring48590.2020.9129493

  • Demel, Monsees, Bockelmann, Wübben, Dekorsy: Cloud-RAN Fronthaul Rate Reduction via IBM-based Quantization for Multicarrier Systems, 24th International ITG Workshop on Smart Antennas (WSA 2020), ISBN: 978-3-8007-5200-3

  • Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy: Industrial Radio Link Abstraction Models for Short Packet Communication with Polar Codes, 12th International ITG Conference on Systems, Communications and Coding 2019, Rostock, Germany, DOI: 10.30420/454862044.

  • Rust, Karsthof, Hao, Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy, Siemons, Meyering, Al Houry, Mackenthun, Paul: Hardwarearchitektur eines latenzoptimierten drahtlosen Kommunikationssystems für den industriellen Mobilfunk, Jahreskolloquium Kommunikation in der Automation 2018, DOI: 10.1007/978-3-662-59895-5_11

  • Hao, Karsthof, Rust, Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy, Al Houry, Mackenthun, Paul: FPGA-based Baseband Solution for High Performance Industrial Wireless Communication, 2018 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Digital Signal Processing (DSP), DOI: 10.1109/ICDSP.2018.8631662

  • Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy, Rode, Koslowski, Jondral: An optimized GFDM software implementation for future Cloud-RAN and field tests, Proceedings of the 7th GNU Radio Conference 2017, San Diego, USA, 2017-09

  • Demel, Bockelmann, Dekorsy: Evaluation of a Software Defined GFDM Implementation for Industry 4.0 Applications, 2017 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Technology (ICIT), Toronto, ON, Canada, DOI: 10.1109/ICIT.2017.7915548

  • Kaushik, Wunsch, Sagainov, Cuervo, Demel, Koslowski, Jäkel, Jondral: Spectrum sharing for 5G wireless systems (Spectrum sharing challenge), 2015 IEEE International Symposium on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (DySPAN), DOI: 10.1109/DySPAN.2015.7343841

  • Demel, Koslowski, Jondral: A LTE Receiver Framework Using GNU Radio, Journal of Signal Processing Systems volume 78, pages 313–320 (2015), DOI: 10.1007/s11265-014-0959-z

  • Demel, Koslowski, Jondral: A LTE Receiver Framework Implementation in GNU Radio, 2013 Wireless Innovation Forum European Conference on Communications Technologies and Software Defined Radio (SDR-WInnComm Europe 2013), 11-13 June 2013, Munich, Germany, pp. 36-40
